title: 114_s1990
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Federal Computer Security Act" and includes definitions for key terms. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Agency.--The term ``agency'' is defined as in section 3502 of title 44, United States Code.
(2) Covered agency.--Refers to an agency operating a Federal computer system with access to classified or personally identifiable information.
(3) Logical access control.--Process of granting or denying specific requests for information and related services.
(4) Multi-factor logical access controls.--Includes at least 2 of the following controls: user-known information, access device, unique biometric characteristic. The Inspector General of each covered agency must submit a report to the Comptroller General and relevant committees within 240 days of the Act's enactment. The report should include information on the logical access standards and multi-factor controls used to access Federal computer systems containing classified or personally identifiable information. The Inspector General of each covered agency must report on the use of logical access controls and multi-factor authentication for accessing Federal computer systems with classified or personally identifiable information. Additionally, the report should detail data security management practices, including software inventories and licensing agreements for security controls. The covered agency must report on the use of software security controls for monitoring threats, including data loss prevention and digital rights management software. They should also describe how the software is being used and provide reasons if they are not using it. Additionally, the agency must describe their policies for ensuring that entities providing services to them implement data security management practices. The covered agency must report on the implementation of data security management practices by entities providing services to them. The report may be based on audits or evaluations and may include a classified annex. It must be made available to Members of Congress upon request. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment, analyzing impediments to agency use of security software and devices. The report may include a classified annex but will be in unclassified form.
